    Joe Biden ‘has blood on his hands’ with Israel-Hamas conflict
    Republican Senator Tim Scott has stated United States President Joe Biden has “blood on his hands” after Hamas’ attack on Israel, says Curtin University Dean of Global Future Joe Siracusa. Mr Siracusa says the conflict between Palestine and Israel began “in earnest” after Biden’s administration “turned over $6 billion for the hostages to Iran”. “Of course, Iran is behind this,” Mr Siracusa told Sky News Australia. “When the history books are written, those will be the opening.” Officials say 4,741 Palestinians and 1,400 Israelis have been killed in the conflict as Israel’s military claims the number of people held hostage has risen to 212.
    Israeli forces bombard Gaza strip again
    Israeli forces are once again bombarding the Gaza Strip with a number of airstrikes as calls continue to grow for additional humanitarian aid to be allowed into the region. Israeli's military struck a mosque in the West Bank overnight.

    FOX 4 meteorologist Ali Turiano talks about the pattern change in the weather and what that means for our rain chances.

    Four people were displaced after a massive fire broke out at a building under construction in Southeast D.C. Sunday.

    It's going to be a windy start to the week!

    Don't miss The Georgia Gang, Atlanta's longest-running public affairs broadcast on FOX 5 Atlanta every Sunday at 8:30 a.m.
    ‘Israeli or Palestinian’: Every life taken in Israel-Hamas conflict is a ‘terrible thing’
    Agriculture Minister Murray Watt says every life taken in the conflict between Israel and Hamas is a “terrible thing”. The Agriculture Minister says since the beginning, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and the Labor government have “condemned Hamas’ attack on innocent Israeli lives”. “We’ve said consistently that Israel has a right to defend itself,” Mr Watt told Sky News Australia. “But that doesn’t get away from the fact that every life in this conflict is worth something. “We don’t want to see any more lives lost than absolutely needed.”
    New Republican candidates enter US speaker race
    Nine Republican candidates have officially entered the race to become the next House speaker after the withdrawal of Jim Jordan. Several have signed a loyalty pledge to support the winner of the first vote, aiming to avoid the vote-counting confusion that followed Mr Jordan’s candidacy. This comes after earlier this month, former US House speaker Kevin McCarthy was ousted. “If we don’t have a speaker of the House, we can’t govern, and every day that goes by, we’re essentially shut down as a government,” Republican Representative Michael McCaul said. A secret vote with the GOP conference is scheduled for Tuesday as Republicans are encouraged to sign a unity pledge, promising to support whoever wins the vote.
    China set to remove tariffs on Australian wine
    Tyrrell's Wines Managing Director Bruce Tyrrell says the industry is going through a “pretty tough time at the moment” as Chinese sanctions on Australian wine are set to be removed. The decision to remove the sanctions clears the way for the Prime Minister to visit Beijing next month. Mr Tyrrell said Chinese wine consumption has dropped by about 60 per cent because “they can’t get the wine that they really like to drink”. “As more and more Chinese people have travelled over the last 10 years, they’ve got to know Australia, they like Australia, they like Australians and got a great taste for Australian wine, so we really need to be back in that market,” he told Sky News Australia. Mr Tyrrell hopes China’s economy will grow and Australian wine sales will grow with it.
    Aerial images show Hamas placing rocket sites next to schools and kindergartens in Gaza
    Images shared by Israel show Hamas rocket sites next to Palestinian schools and kindergartens in Gaza.

    Iran jails 2 journalists who covered hijab death row, for 'collaborating with US'
    Two journalists in Iran have been sentenced to up to seven years in prison for collaborating with the US government and other charges. Niloufar Hamedi and Elaheh Mohammadi were imprisoned for over a year following their coverage of Mahsa Amini's death in police custody. The New York-based Committee to Protect Journalists has condemned the decision and called for their release. The journalists were charged with collaborating with the US government, colluding against national security, and propaganda against the system. Their detentions have sparked international criticism over the security force crackdown after Amini's death.  ( 41 min )

    Israel 'accidentally' fires at Egyptian post; 2nd aid convoy on way to Gaza
    A second aid convoy entered the Egyptian side of the Rafah border crossing on Sunday, heading towards Gaza. Shortly after the convoy entered, a blast was heard and seven people were wounded. The Israeli military said one of its tanks accidentally fired and hit an Egyptian position near the border. The Egyptian military said the blast caused minor injuries and that an investigation is underway. The convoy carried medical and food supplies, and distribution of the supplies began on Sunday. However, aid officials are warning of a humanitarian disaster as supplies run low.  ( 41 min )
    Antisemitism, Islamophobia on rise in West
    Advocacy groups have reported a significant increase in antisemitic and Islamophobic incidents in the US and Europe since the recent Hamas attacks in Israel. The Anti-Defamation League recorded a 55% rise in antisemitic incidents in the US compared to the same period last year. There have also been spikes in anti-Israel rallies and antisemitic harassment on messaging apps. Similarly, the Council on American-Islamic Relations reported an increase in anti-Muslim incidents in the past week. In the UK, anti-Muslim attacks have increased sixfold, while France and Germany have also seen a rise in antisemitic incidents.  ( 42 min )
    How diplomacy helped set free mom-daughter
    US Secretary of State Antony Blinken spoke with Qatar's PM about the issue of the hostages held by Hamas during the recent attack on Israel. Qatar played a significant role in delicate talks involving multiple countries to secure the release of the captives. When Hamas released two captives, the Raanan family, US officials thanked Qatar for their involvement. Families of the remaining hostages hope this is just the beginning. The hostages have likely been split into small groups, and it is unclear why the Raanans were released first, although their American nationality may have played a role.  ( 43 min )
    Israel strikes a 'terror compound' in West Bank
    The Israeli military conducted an airstrike on a mosque in the occupied West Bank, resulting in the death of at least two people. The strike targeted an underground compound allegedly being used by Hamas and Islamic Jihad for organizing an imminent attack. The Palestinian foreign ministry condemned the airstrike as a "dangerous escalation" and accused Israel of using tactics from the Gaza Strip in the West Bank. Violence in the area has increased following recent attacks by Hamas.  ( 41 min )
    Pentagon sees threat to US troops in West Asia, beefs up military assets
    US officials, including Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin, have expressed concerns about the potential escalation of attacks on US troops in the West Asia region. They also mentioned the possibility of Iran trying to expand the Israel-Hamas conflict. The US has recently deployed additional military assets to the region, including a Thaad battery and extra Patriot battalions, to prevent the conflict from spreading. The US has already sent significant naval power and has troops stationed in Iraq and Syria.  ( 42 min )
    Israel pummels Gaza amid fear of wider war
    The Israel-Hamas conflict has raised concerns about a wider conflict in the region. Israel has continued to bombard Gaza, with the death toll rising. Clashes between Hezbollah and Israeli forces along the Lebanon border have also escalated. Israeli missiles have hit airports in Syria, where Iran has a military presence. Israel has warned of a potential ground offensive in Gaza, while also evacuating communities close to the Lebanon border. The situation remains tense, with fears of further escalation.  ( 46 min )
    China, Philippines row over collisions in disputed sea
    Beijing and Manila traded blame on Sunday for two collisions between Chinese vessels and Philippine boats on a resupply mission to Filipino troops near Second Thomas Shoal in the Spratly Islands in the disputed South China Sea.  ( 38 min )

    South East Asia celebrates Netaji, reaffirms to honour legacy
    The chief minister of Penang, Malaysia, Chow Kon Yeow, attended a commemorative event for Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose, marking the 80th anniversary of the provisional government and INA Raising Day. He expressed pride that Netaji had chosen Malaysia as a base to organize Indians against British colonial rule. In Bangkok, the Netaji Subhash Vision Thailand organization celebrated the anniversary with a 3-day "Netaji Pilgrimage" for academics and Indo-Thai citizens connected to Bose's historical visits to Thailand. The first-ever INA training camp was built in Chonburi, Thailand, where Indian migrant families supported Netaji's cause.  ( 43 min )
    China to build world's largest underwater 'ghost particle' detector
    China is constructing the world's largest underwater microscope, the Tropical Deep-sea Neutrino Telescope (TRIDENT), to hunt for elusive neutrinos or "ghost particles" in the Western Pacific Ocean. Set to be completed in 2030, TRIDENT aims to capture neutrinos as they become detectable in the deep ocean depths, providing insights into their cosmic origins.  ( 42 min )
    Pulitzer winner's New York talk cancelled over Gaza stand
    Viet Thanh Nguyen, a Pulitzer Prize-winning author, had a reading event cancelled by a Jewish organization in New York City, a day after he signed an open letter condemning Israel's actions in Gaza. The organization, 92nd Street Y, postponed the event without giving a reason or offering an alternative date. The organization cited Nguyen's stance on Israel and the recent attack by Hamas as reasons for the postponement. Nguyen's representatives have not commented on the cancellation.  ( 40 min )
    Pangea Ultima: The uninhabitable supercontinent of Earth's distant future
    Scientists at the University of Bristol have used supercomputer climate models to predict the formation of a future supercontinent called Pangea Ultima, which is expected to occur 250 million years from now. This continent will bring extreme temperatures, rendering it uninhabitable for mammals. The study attributes the dramatic increase in temperatures to heightened volcanism and the sun emitting more energy and heat as it ages. The research provides insights into how Earth's climate might change in the distant future due to natural processes. Despite concerns about contemporary climate change, the Earth is expected to remain habitable until the emergence of Pangea Ultima.  ( 47 min )
    Geological time capsules: Diamonds tell the tale of Earth's ancient continents
    An international team of experts has analyzed ancient superdeep diamonds found in mines in Brazil and Western Africa to gain new insights into the early evolution of complex life on Earth. These rare diamonds, formed within the supercontinent Gondwana, provide information about the formation and movement of supercontinents. The research reveals that supercontinents played a role in concentrating deep oceanic plate subduction. The diamonds formed deep beneath Gondwana and were carried to the surface during volcanic eruptions.  ( 49 min )
    Amazon testing humanoid robots in its warehouses
    Amazon plans to test Agility's bipedal robot, Digit, in its nationwide fulfillment centers. Amazon Robotics has primarily focused on wheeled autonomous mobile robots (AMRs), but their interest in Digit shows their curiosity about walking robots and their potential. The integration of humanoid robots into Amazon's operations raises questions about scalability and adaptability. While this early-stage deal may not guarantee broader adoption, it highlights Amazon's interest in exploring robotics.  ( 44 min )
    Pope, Biden discuss Israel-Hamas conflict, other wars
    Pope Francis and US president Joe Biden engaged in a 20-minute telephone conversation on Sunday, during which they discussed the Israel-Hamas conflict and various other ongoing wars, as reported by the Vatican. The focus of their discussion was on addressing conflict situations worldwide and finding ways to promote peace. In parallel news, Israel is preparing for a ground assault on Gaza, prompted by a recent Hamas attack in Israel that resulted in the loss of 1,400 lives.  ( 41 min )
    Argentina heads to polls in grip of fierce economic crisis
    Argentines will vote in a general election on Sunday amid the country's worst economic crisis in two decades. The far-right libertarian candidate Javier Milei is in pole position to win, promising to bring about radical change in the economy and politics. However, centrist Peronist Economy Minister Sergio Massa and conservative Patricia Bullrich are also strong contenders. The election outcome will have significant implications for Argentina's markets, trade relationships, and political trajectory.  ( 47 min )
    Amid slump in economy, Pakistanis migrating abroad for better opportunities
    Amid an economic downturn and hyperinflation, many Pakistanis, particularly the younger generation, are seeking opportunities abroad for employment and scholarships. Over 450,000 Pakistanis are reported to have emigrated in the first three months of 2023. Passport offices and immigration centers are witnessing long queues as people rush to obtain passports and visas. The British Council is also experiencing a surge in work and student visa applications. Some believe that this mass exodus can lead to increased international remittances benefiting Pakistan.  ( 43 min )
    No wish for revenge, Nawaz Sharif tells supporters on returning to Pakistan

He arrived in Lahore to a huge rally of supporters and vowed to work for the well-being of the public. Sharif's return is seen as part of a deal with the military establishment, despite being disqualified from electoral politics. Police said it was a targeted attack carried out by unknown masked men in Mirali area of the North Waziristan tribal district on Friday morning. Malik was targeted by masked men at a private clinic and the assailants managed to escape after the attack. Malik is said to be the founder of Lashkar-e-Jabbar and also a close aide of one of India’s most wanted terrorists Azhar.  ( 40 min )
    Russian strikes kill 3 in Ukraine

    Hostage release: Qatar can play key role

    ‘I am a Zionist’: Biden had told Netanyahu during visit

This revelation highlights Biden's long-standing support for Israel, which is now being tested as he tries to balance his unwavering support with the need to prevent further casualties and humanitarian crisis in Gaza. Biden's strong connection to Israel is deeply ingrained in his political DNA and will be a challenge he must navigate.  ( 41 min )

  • Open

    Gallup Poll: Trust In US News Media Hits A Record Low
    Gallup: Media Confidence in U.S. Matches 2016 Record Low  * 32% have a “great deal” or “fair amount” of trust in media’s news reporting  * New high of 39% have no confidence at all, compared with 27% in 2016  * Democrats’ trust is down 12 points since last year; lowest since 2016  WASHINGTON, D.C. -- The 32% of Americans who say they trust the mass media “a great deal” or “a fair amount” to report the news in a full, fair and accurate way ties Gallup’s lowest historical reading, previously recorded in 2016. Although trust in media currently matches the historical low, it was statistically similar in 2021 (36%) and 2022 (34%).  Another 29% of U.S. adults have “not very much” trust, while a record-high 39% register “none at all.” This nearly four in 10 Americans who completely lack confidence in the media is the highest on record by one percentage point. It is 12 points higher than the 2016 reading, which came amid sharp criticism of the media from then-presidential candidate Donald Trump -- making the current assessment of the media the grimmest in Gallup’s history. In 2016, U.S. adults were most likely to say they had “not very much” trust (41%).  Read more ....  Update #1: Trust in media matches lowest historical reading: Gallup (The Hill)  Update #2: Confidence in US news media hits record low – poll (RT)  WNU Editor: I am surprised that 32% of Americans still trust their news media.
    Cairo Peace Summit Fails To Find Consensus On The Israeli-Hamas War
    VOA: Cairo Summit Fails to Find Consensus on Israeli-Palestinian Conflict   * No consensus at the Cairo Summit on the Israel-Palestinian violence.  * The Rafah crossing between Gaza and Egypt opened Saturday, allowing the transportation of humanitarian aid.  * Clashes between Israel and Hamas continue, with Israeli airstrikes killing 19 people in Gaza, according to Palestinian media.  * Israel issued a warning advising its citizens against traveling to Egypt, Jordan and Morocco, and if they are in those countries to leave as soon as possible.  A Cairo summit hosted by Egypt Saturday failed to reach an agreement on how to contain the violence between Israel and Hamas.  Arab leaders condemned the Israeli bombardment of Gaza while mostly Western countries said civilians should be shielded, but with Israel and senior U.S. officials absent there was no consensus on how to resolve the conflict.  Read more ....   WNU Editor: Another indication that this crisis is spiraling out of control.  Cairo Peace Summit Fails To Find Consensus On Ending The Israeli-Hamas War   At Cairo peace summit, Arab leaders express growing anger with Israel over its war in Gaza -- AP  Cairo Peace Summit ends without Gaza breakthrough -- Reuters   World leaders at Cairo Peace Summit call for civilian safety in Gaza -- UPI   World leaders attend Cairo peace summit to ‘de-escalate’ Israel-Hamas war -- Al JAzeera   Peace Summit in Egypt Shows a Shift in Rhetoric but no Consensus -- New York Times

    Argentine Voters Go To The Polls To Elect A New President This Sunday
    BBC: Argentina election: Javier Milei, TikTok economist, leads polls  Argentina votes on Sunday in one of the most open presidential elections for decades.  The effects of a deep economic crisis have proved fertile ground for an unorthodox far-right front-runner, with wild hair, big sideburns and a totally radical approach to ruling the country.  Javier Milei was, until recently, a relative unknown. An economist, pundit and rock fan, he came top in recent primaries and polls now put him ahead in Sunday's first round. He is very clear about wanting to shake things up. At one campaign event, he wielded a chainsaw to send a message that he intends to slash spending to improve Argentina's economy.   Read more .... WNU Editor: Inflation in Argentina is now at 138%.     Pentagon Report Says China’s Nuclear Arsenal On Track To Double By 2030
    Washington Post: China’s nuclear arsenal on track to double by 2030, Pentagon reports  China has developed an arsenal of more than 500 operational nuclear warheads and is set to double that number by the end of the decade, exceeding previous Pentagon estimates, according to a Defense Department report.  The figures, released in an unclassified public report to Congress on Thursday, are part of a broad assessment of China’s military goals and developments in the past year, and highlight the rapid advances in Beijing’s multi-decade plan to build a nuclear weapons arsenal that rivals that of the United States.   Read more ....   WNU Editor: China has responded to this US report ....     Albanese and Biden to discuss AUKUS progress
    Industry Minister Ed Husic says there will be discussions on “how to progress” AUKUS as well as energy talks between US President Joe Biden and Prime Minister Anthony Albanese. Mr Husic’s comments come after the Prime Minister announced a trip to Washington. The Industry Minister said there is a commitment by the United Kingdom, United States and Australian governments to proceed. “Clearly, there will be discussion on how to progress that along with other matters that are relevant to the relations,” Mr Husic told Sky News Australia. “Not the least of which being the energy transition and how we can work together on that.”

Founded by four friends in a pub in 2018, the collective's campaigns and stunts skewering politicians and spotlighting issues get millions of views online -- and often generate mainstream media coverage. They remain best known for their light-hearted early efforts, like plastering ex-prime minister Boris Johnson's optimistic tweets about the joys of life after Brexit to contrast them with the reality.     Top China beer maker opens probe after worker urination video
    One of China's biggest beer makers said it had opened an investigation after a video appearing to show a factory employee urinating on raw ingredients went viral this week. The clip, published online on Thursday, purportedly shows a male worker at a Tsingtao Brewery Co. warehouse clambering into a high-walled container and relieving himself onto its contents. The footage circulated widely on Chinese social media, racking up tens of millions of views on the popular platform Weibo. Tsingtao said on Friday that it had contacted the police over the incident and an investigation was ongoing. "Our company attaches high importance to the relevant video that emerged from Tsingtao Brewery No. 3 on October 19," the beermaker said in a statement. "We reported the incident to the police at the earliest opportunity, and public security organs are involved in the investigation," it added. "At present, the batch of malt in question has been completely sealed. The company continues to strengthen its management procedures and ensure product quality." Many social media users reacted to the video with anger and voiced support for one of China's best-known beverage brands. "I suggest the company takes this man to court and gets him to pay compensation for the damages," read one popular Weibo response to the company's statement. "Investigate this thoroughly! Always stand up for our national champion brands!" wrote another user. Hong Kong-listed Tsingtao is China's second-largest brewer, and its tall bottles of crisp lager are perennial fridge-fillers in bars across East Asia. In recent years, the company has sought to capitalise on the changing tastes of younger Chinese drinkers by diversifying into craft ales and other products. Some web users were not about to pass up the chance to make a wry quip about the country's famously light and fizzy mass-market brews. "I've always said the beer here is like horse pee. Turns out I was wrong," one of them commented. "Thanks, I think I'll have wine instead," quipped another.  ( 42 min )

    Veteran NYPD officer allegedly sold ‘top quality’ fentanyl, heroin while on duty: Feds
    A female NYPD officer and a man from Yonkers have been arrested for allegedly distributing drugs, including fentanyl and heroin. The officer, Grace Rose Baez, is accused of selling narcotics to an undercover federal informant while on active duty. She provided a sample of fentanyl and offered to sell one kilogram of heroin and 800 grams of fentanyl to the informant. The transactions took place while Baez was on desk duty at an NYPD facility. Baez and the man she was arrested with, Cesar Martinez, have been charged with conspiracy to distribute narcotics.  ( 40 min )
    About 100,000 protesters join pro-Palestinian march through London
    Around 100,000 people gathered in London to participate in a pro-Palestinian demonstration, calling for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza. The protesters marched through the city, chanting slogans and waving Palestinian flags, before congregating at Downing Street. The event, organized by the Palestine Solidarity Campaign, remained peaceful, with only 10 arrests made by the police. The demonstration comes amidst a significant increase in antisemitic and Islamophobic offenses in the UK.  ( 42 min )
    Over one thousand migrants reach Spain's Canary Islands in single day
    Over 1,000 migrants arrived in Spain's Canary Islands in a single day, with a boat carrying 320 people being the most crowded vessel ever seen by rescuers. The Red Cross reported that a wooden boat arriving on the island of El Hierro marked record arrivals. The Canary Islands have become the main destination for migrants trying to reach Spain, resulting in an 80% increase in attempted crossings compared to last year. Spain's migration minister has pledged a 50 million euro aid package to help the Canary Islands.  ( 42 min )
    'Glad you're out': Biden talks to 2 US hostages freed by Hamas
    US President Joe Biden celebrated the release of two American hostages from Gaza with a phone call. The hostages, a mother and daughter who were abducted by Hamas, expressed their gratitude to Biden for his support. During the call, Biden promised to rescue the remaining 10 Americans still held captive. The US, along with European allies, is urging Israel to exercise restraint and negotiate for the release of the remaining hostages.  ( 43 min )
    Situation in Gaza 'catastrophic': five UN agencies
    The United Nations agencies have called for more international assistance as the humanitarian situation in the Gaza Strip deteriorates. Israel has announced plans to increase strikes in Gaza, while the UN agencies highlight that over 1.6 million people in Gaza are in critical need of aid, with children, pregnant women, and the elderly being the most vulnerable. The agencies describe the situation as catastrophic and urge the world to do more to address the crisis.  ( 41 min )
    Ex-Philadelphia police officer sentenced to 15 to 40 years after guilty pleas in sex assault cases
    A former Philadelphia police officer has been sentenced to 15 to 40 years in prison after pleading guilty to sexually assaulting women and girls, including child sex assault, child pornography, and kidnapping. Patrick Heron, who posed as an active officer to lure victims, was accused of predatory behavior spanning years and involving dozens of vulnerable young women and girls. Investigators have identified 48 victims, but many remain unknown and may not have come forward.  ( 42 min )
    Turkish pianist's concerts in Switzerland cancelled over Israel criticism
    Turkish composer and pianist Fazil Say has had his concerts in Switzerland cancelled due to his social media posts criticizing Israeli policies in Gaza. The concerts were organized by the event unit of retail company Migros, who cited Say's ideas expressed on social media as the reason for the cancellation. Say had previously criticized both Israel and Hamas, expressing his support for peace. The cancellation has been condemned by Omer Celik, spokesman for Turkish President.  ( 47 min )
    UN aid chief says second aid convoy for Gaza could lead to sustained relief
    The United Nations is planning to send a second convoy of trucks into Gaza, hoping to scale up relief deliveries in the coming week. The first convoy of 20 trucks arrived on Saturday, but further deliveries have been delayed due to Israeli demands for aid verification. UN aid chief Martin Griffiths stated that negotiations are underway for another convoy of 20 to 30 trucks. The UN emphasizes the importance of continuous aid to meet essential needs in Gaza, where Israel has imposed a total siege.  ( 41 min )
    Biden speaks to freed American-Israeli hostages
    US President Joe Biden expressed his joy and gratitude for the release of Judith and Natalie Raanan, who were held captive in the Gaza Strip. The mother and daughter were kidnapped during Hamas's invasion of southern Israel. Biden credited the governments of Qatar and Israel for their partnership in securing their release. The Israel Defense Forces have notified 210 families that their loved ones have been kidnapped, including children and elderly individuals, from various countries.  ( 42 min )
    Civilians killed and wounded as Russian forces renew push to take towns in eastern Ukraine
    At least three civilians were killed and others wounded in Ukraine on Friday and Saturday, as Russian forces continued to shell areas across the country and pushed forward near an embattled eastern city, local Ukrainian officials reported Saturday. A man died as Russian forces shelled the Ukrainian-held town of Nikopol from their stronghold at Ukraine's largest nuclear plant, according to Ukrainian local Gov. Serhii Lysak. Lysak said that emergency services in Nikopol were working to assess the damage.  ( 52 min )
    Cyclone 'Tej' expected to make landfall between Yemen and Oman on October 25
    The Indian Meteorological Department (IMD) Saturday said that the Severe Cyclonic Storm "Tej," has been steadily advancing over the southwest Arabian Sea. In the past 6 hours, the storm has moved west-northwestwards at a speed of 18 kmph. As of 1730 hours Indian Standard Time (IST) on October 21, "Tej" was positioned approximately 440 km east-southeast of Socotra, Yemen, 800 km south-southeast of Salalah, Oman, and 830 km southeast of Al Ghaidah, Yemen.  ( 42 min )

    Hurricane Norma, now Category 2, nears west Mexico coast
    Hurricane Norma is set to hit Mexico's northwestern coast with strong winds, flooding, and dangerous sea surges. The storm, downgraded to a Category 2, is heading towards the popular tourist destination of Cabo San Lucas. As of now, it is 65 kilometers away from the town and moving at a speed of 15 kilometers per hour. Authorities have warned of the potential for flash flooding and mudslides in higher terrain. Hotel employees have advised guests to stay indoors until the storm passes.  ( 43 min )
    Storm Babet triggers flooding, power cuts in northern Europe
    Deadly Storm Babet unleashed extensive flooding and damaged towns in Denmark and Norway late Friday and early Saturday, while continuing to sweep across the UK. Three people died in Scotland and England and families were trapped in flooded homes on Friday as the storm battered Britain and Ireland. After it made landfall in Scandinavia, the storm triggered a sharp rise in water levels in towns in southern Denmark, flooding the first floor of homes which were left without power for several hours.  ( 48 min )
    'Erratic' Hurricane Norma on track to hit Mexico's Baja California
    Hurricane Norma is strengthening as it moves towards the southern tip of Mexico's Baja California peninsula. The storm is expected to bring heavy rainfall and strong winds to popular tourist resorts in the area. The governor has urged people to stay indoors and businesses to close. Shelters have been set up to accommodate up to 10,000 people. The National Hurricane Center warns of dangerous conditions and possible flooding. Norma is located some 195 miles (314 km) south of Cabo San Lucas.  ( 44 min )

    AP PHOTOS: Grief, devastation overwhelm region in second week of Israel-Hamas war
    A wounded Palestinian child, crying and clutching onto adults carrying him into a hospital. A deceased Israeli soldier's loved ones, their faces wracked with grief as they mourn. Dozens of small posters, each one picturing a missing Israeli, as another sign blares just one word, scribbled in bright red: “Pain.” The images tell a story of unspeakable tragedy and palpable fear, as the war between Israel and Hamas prepares to enter its third week. The deadliest of the five Gaza wars, it has left more than 1,400 people in Israel dead, as well as more than 4,100 Palestinians, according to the Hamas-run Gaza Health Ministry. The destruction is clear throughout Gaza, as Palestinians desperately search for survivors and are forced to walk through rubble left behind after Israeli bombardments. And anguish continues to ripple throughout Israel, as mothers bury their children, flags and flowers line even more graves, and couples become separated as one partner heads into combat. Others,...  ( 8 min )

    Biden says Hamas attack aimed to disrupt Saudi-Israel normalization ties
    President Joe Biden has stated that Hamas' recent attack on Israel was aimed at disrupting the potential normalization of ties between Israel and Saudi Arabia. Saudi Arabia, which has not followed its Gulf neighbors in establishing relations with Israel, has stated that Palestinian statehood goals should be addressed first. Biden had plans to sit down with the Saudis, making the potential normalization of relations a top priority for Secretary of State Antony Blinken during his trip to Riyadh.  ( 42 min )
    US commitment to Ukraine a central question as Biden meets with EU heads during congressional chaos
    President Joe Biden assured European Union leaders during their meeting at the White House that the United States will provide substantial aid to Ukraine and Israel. Biden emphasized the unity between the US and EU in supporting Ukraine and tackling economic challenges, while also discussing the need to back Israel after the recent Hamas attack and establish trade standards with China.  ( 60 min )
    IOC hits back at Putin claim of 'ethnic discrimination' against Russia's potential Olympic athletes
    The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has dismissed claims by Russian President Vladimir Putin of "ethnic discrimination" against athletes excluded from international sport. The IOC has advised sports bodies to vet Russian athletes for competing as neutral individuals without national identity for the 2024 Paris Olympics. The IOC stated that these measures are a reaction to the breach of the Olympic Charter by the Russian and Belarusian governments.  ( 47 min )
    2 American hostages freed: Hamas
    The armed wing of Hamas, the Izz el-Deen al-Qassam Brigades, has released two US hostages from Gaza for humanitarian reasons, according to their spokesman. The release came as a response to Qatari mediation efforts in the war with Israel. The Israeli and American officials have not confirmed or denied the claim. Hamas had previously stated that they took around 200 hostages during their rampage on Israeli towns, and they have released some of them. The Israeli military has stated that most of the hostages are still alive, including over 20 children.  ( 41 min )
    United Kingdom's Labour deals big by-poll blows to Sunak
    Britain's Labour Party dealt a crushing blow to PM Rishi Sunak's Conservatives on Friday, winning two previously safe parliamentary seats in victories leader Keir Starmer said showed voters wanted change at the next national election. The double defeat showed a big slump in support for the governing Conservatives, who have won the last four national votes, and suggests Labour is on course to win power for the first time since 2010 at an election expected next year. While so-called by-elections are often lost by the governing party, the scale of the defeat in two parliamentary seats the Conservatives have held for years piles pressure on Sunak.  ( 41 min )
    United States shoots down drones & missiles from Yemen
    A US navy warship intercepted three cruise missiles and several drones launched from Yemen towards Israel. The missiles and drones were launched by pro-Iranian Houthi rebels, highlighting the risk of the conflict between Israel and Hamas escalating into a wider war. The Biden administration has deployed additional troops and aircraft carriers to deter Iran and its proxies from engaging in a regional war. The US military is assessing the responsible party for the drone attacks. The Pentagon spokesman emphasized the importance of containing the conflict and stated that any American response would be determined by the US.  ( 44 min )
    Trump fined $5,000 by New York judge for violating gag order
    Former US President Donald Trump has been fined $5,000 by a New York judge for violating a partial gag order. The judge also warned Trump of possible jail time for future violations. The gag order was imposed after Trump insulted the judge's law clerk on social media. Trump and his two sons are facing charges of inflating the value of Trump Organization assets.  ( 46 min )
    West Bank a possible 'third front' for Israel
    Violence in the West Bank has escalated amid ongoing clashes between Israeli soldiers and settlers and Palestinians. Concerns are rising that the territory could become a third front in a wider conflict, following Israel's bombardment of Gaza and clashes with Hezbollah at the Lebanon border. Over 80 Palestinians have been killed and more than 900 people have been arrested since October 7. The violence poses a challenge to both Israel and the Palestinian Authority, with growing support for armed resistance. The Israeli military is on high alert, anticipating attacks from Hamas militants in the West Bank.  ( 41 min )
    Israel prepares for a 3-phase war against Hamas
    Israel launched airstrikes on the Gaza Strip, targeting areas where Palestinians had sought safety, and started evacuating an Israeli town near Lebanon's border, indicating a possible ground invasion. Israel's defense minister stated that they do not plan to control civilians in Gaza after their war with Hamas and expect a three-phase war. The Israeli military struck more than 100 targets tied to Hamas. Palestinian militants have launched over 6,900 rockets into Israel, causing tensions in the West Bank. Over one million people have been displaced in Gaza, with overwhelmed hospitals rationing medical supplies and fuel. Aid delivery from Egypt remains uncertain.  ( 47 min )
    Italy PM Giorgia Meloni announces separation from partner after his sexist TV comments
    Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni has announced her separation from her partner, TV journalist Andrea Giambruno, who has faced backlash for making sexist comments. Meloni stated that she should not be judged for his remarks and will no longer address questions about his behavior. The split comes as Meloni marks her first year in office, leading a right-wing coalition government that prioritizes traditional family values. The couple, who have a 7-year-old daughter, had been together for nearly 10 years. Giambruno's controversial comments and actions have been a subject of public scrutiny.  ( 42 min )
    Hamas releases American mother and daughter held hostage after Qatari mediation
    Two American hostages, Judith Tai Raanan and her daughter Natalie Shoshana Raanan, who were abducted by Hamas during their stay at Kibbutz Nahal Oz., have been freed and identified as Chicago-area residents are en-route to a military base in central Israel. They were handed over to Israeli forces at the border of the Gaza Strip and are being reunited with their family. The release of the two hostages was made possible through a partnership between Qatar and Israel.  ( 57 min )
    Judge threatens to hold Donald Trump in contempt after deleted post is found on campaign website
    Judge Arthur Engoron, who is presiding over Donald Trump's civil fraud trial, threatened to hold the former president in contempt for violating a court order. Trump's disparaging social media post about a court staffer remained on his campaign website for weeks after the judge ordered it to be deleted. Engoron warned of possible fines or even jail time for Trump. The judge had issued a limited gag order, prohibiting personal attacks on court staff involved in the case.  ( 59 min )
    Turkey says Biden's Israel visit amounted to approval of destruction in Gaza
    Turkish Foreign Minister Hakan Fidan expressed concerns about US President Joe Biden's visit to Israel, suggesting it appeared to endorse the destruction in Gaza, highlighting that this would be remembered in history. Speaking to state broadcaster TRT Haber, Fidan said Israel had "changed the narrative" about its involvement in a blast at a Gaza hospital on Tuesday, and added he hoped a summit in Cairo on Saturday would yield an agreement to stop Israel's offensive.  ( 41 min )
    Republicans drop Jim Jordan as Speaker nominee after failed 3rd vote
    Representative Jim Jordan of Ohio has lost an internal vote to continue as the nominee for speaker within his party, creating further uncertainty in the House. This comes after his third unsuccessful attempt to secure the position. With no consensus on a path forward, the House is paralyzed despite growing pressure to address urgent matters. Jordan's loss reveals that he had actually lost ground, with 25 Republicans opposing him compared to 22 in his previous attempt. The Republican party now needs to find a new candidate for speaker.  ( 49 min )
    Biden says Gaza aid likely to cross in 'next 24 to 48 hours'
    US President Joe Biden said he believes that the first aid trucks to reach Gaza via the Rafah crossing from Egypt within the next 24 to 48 hours, with a commitment from Israel and Egypt to facilitate the aid despite the need for road repairs. "I believe in the next 24 to 48 hours the first 20 trucks will come across the border," Biden said as he met European Union chiefs at the White House.  ( 37 min )
    Another Trump lawyer reaches plea deal with Georgia prosecutors
    Kenneth Chesebro, a lawyer for Donald Trump's 2020 election campaign, pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit filing of false documents in the Georgia election case just before his trial. This follows Sidney Powell's guilty plea. These developments prevent the first trial and are part of four state or federal cases against Trump for his efforts to reverse the election results. Meanwhile, Trump maintains his innocence and asserts his loss was due to fraud.  ( 40 min )
    Egypt peace summit may struggle to foster unity on Gaza conflict
    Egypt is hosting a summit on the Gaza crisis, but the absence of key leaders, including the US, has lowered expectations for its outcome. The summit aims to bring together Arab and European heads of state to discuss the ongoing conflict in Gaza and the future of the Palestinian issue. However, there is uncertainty about who will attend, with no confirmation from the US, China, or Russia. Arab countries have expressed anger at Israel's actions in Gaza.  ( 52 min )
    In Lebanon, thousands are displaced from border towns by clashes, stretching state resources
    Over 4,200 people have been displaced from villages in south Lebanon due to clashes on the border with Israel. Local officials are concerned about the lack of resources and preparation for a larger exodus if the conflict escalates. Many of the displaced individuals are staying in schools in the city of Tyre, but resources are limited. The Lebanese government has appealed to international organizations for assistance. The ongoing clashes have killed at least 22 people in Lebanon.  ( 54 min )
    IMF proposes Pakistan to adopt austerity in new development projects
    The International Monetary Fund (IMF) proposed strict austerity measures for Pakistan's development budget, expressing concerns over the allocation of funds for new projects. The IMF suggests that funds should be allocated to ongoing projects that are near completion instead of starting new ones. IMF also suggested for recovery of Rs 46 billion loss of gas companies from July to September.     Trucks mass at Gaza border as they wait to bring aid to desperate Palestinians
    Satellite photos analyzed Friday by The Associated Press show a long convoy of trucks filled with humanitarian aid waiting to cross the border from Egypt to the Gaza Strip. More than 200 trucks carrying roughly 3,000 tons of aid were positioned near the crossing, according to aid officials. The provisions are intended to bring some relief to the Palestinians in Gaza, which is being blockaded by Israel in response to the Oct. 7 attack by Hamas militants on towns in southern Israel. Many in Gaza, reduced to eating one meal a day and without enough water to drink, are waiting desperately for the aid. It was unclear whether fuel would be allowed across to power hospital generators. On Friday, workers began repairing damaged to the crossing caused by Israeli bombings. Officials hoped to open the crossing on Saturday.  ( 7 min )

"With great sadness, I have now confirmed that several of my relatives (including Viola and Yara pictured here) were killed at Saint Porphyrius Orthodox Church in Gaza, where they had been sheltering, when part of the complex was destroyed as the result of an Israeli airstrike."     To Attain the SDGs, We Must End Female Genital Mutilation
    NAIROBI, Oct 20 (IPS) - The tips of our fingers have densely packed nerve endings. That is why a miniscule paper cut activates our pain receptors and causes stubborn pain for a day or two. Now consider that a clitoris has over 10,000 nerve endings. It is the human female’s most sensitive erogenous zone, explaining the sexual pleasure it elicits at the slightest touch. A paper cut on your clitoris would be agonizing yet does not compare to the pain of female genital mutilation – or FGM. Read the full story, “To Attain the SDGs, We Must End Female Genital Mutilation”, on globalissues.org →  ( 6 min )

    Astronomers Spot Most Distant Fast Radio Burst Ever Detected
    ArticleIFY Astronomers Spot Most Distant Fast Radio Burst Ever Detected Astronomers have observed an extraordinarily distant and powerful fast radio burst (FRB) that released a massive burst of energy in a fraction of a second. FRBs are intense, millisecond-long radio wave flashes with unknown cosmic origins. Since the first detection in 2007, hundreds have been spotted flickering from distant points in space. Read More: Webb […] Astronomers Spot Most Distant Fast Radio Burst Ever Detected Articleify Desk

    Euro-Med Human Rights Monitor Says A Quarter Of Northern Gaza Has Been Destroyed. UN Says 4,200 People Killed After 10 Days
    Relief Web: Israel destroys a quarter of northern Gaza Strip, Palestinian death toll exceeds 4,000  Geneva – Israel is conducting the largest campaign of destruction of buildings and residential houses in the Gaza Strip in modern history, Euro-Med Human Rights Monitor stated, as part of a wide-scale military attack ongoing since the seventh of this month.  Euro-Med Monitor emphasised that Israel is focusing its attacks on the Gaza and North Gaza governorates through a systematic destruction campaign, aiming to force displacement and population transfer against the residents of these governorates.  The Israeli army has warned the residents of both governorates, which are home to nearly a million people, to evacuate the areas and move to the central and southern sections of the Strip, a measure that raises serious legal and humanitarian concerns as it endangers the safety of civilians.   Read more ....   Update #1: Gaza war death toll rises to 4,137 (Economic Times)   Update #2: UN says 4,200 people killed in Israel, Gaza conflict in 10 days (Anadolu Agency)   WNU Editor: The numbers are horrifying. As of yesterday (link here), just in Gaza alone 3,785 Palestinians have been killed in Israeli strikes since Oct.7. Of this 3,785 total, 1,524 were children and 1,000 were women.   Update #3: These shortages have the potential to be just as destructive as bombs if not alleviated soon ....     The Hill: Americans urged to leave Lebanon ‘as soon as possible’  The State Department on Thursday urged Americans to make plans to leave Lebanon “as soon as possible,” elevating an earlier security warning that advised Americans not to travel to the country.  “The U.S. Embassy is closely monitoring the security situation in Lebanon,” the Thursday advisory read.  “The Department of State urges U.S. citizens in Lebanon to make plans to depart as soon as possible while commercial options are still available.”   Read more ....   Update #1: US, UK call on their citizens to leave Lebanon while flights 'remain available' (Times of Israel)   Update #2: US embassy urges its citizens in Lebanon to leave 'ASAP' (Jerusalem Post)   WNU Editor: The US is not the only one telling its citizens to leave ....     FOX News: US conducts nuclear test in Nevada hours after Russian move to revoke global test ban   The test came hours after Russian lawmakers said they plan to revoke the ratification of a global nuclear test ban treaty  The U.S. conducted a high-explosive experiment at a nuclear test site in Nevada hours after Russia revoked a ban on atomic-weapons testing, which Moscow said would put it on par with the United States.  Wednesday's test used chemicals and radioisotopes to "validate new predictive explosion models" that can help detect atomic blasts in other countries, Bloomberg reported, citing the Department of Energy.  "These experiments advance our efforts to develop new technology in support of U.S. nuclear nonproliferation goals," Corey Hinderstein, Deputy Administrator for Defense N…

    Hundreds of US students cross the border daily to attend college in Tijuana
    Thousands of students in Mexico commute daily to attend school in the U.S. But there are also those who travel each day in the opposite direction. Over the past few years, Centro de Ensenanza Tecnica y Superior (CETYS) in Tijuana has worked hard to appeal to students north of the border. Today, residents in the US make up 10% of the university's population.
    Russian American journalist detained in Russia
    This week, Russian authorities detained Alsu Kurmasheva, a journalist who works for the US-funded Radio Free Europe Radio Liberty news service. The dual US-Russian citizen was accused of failing to register as a foreign agent and collecting information about the Russian military as a “foreign entity.”

The current Israel-Hamas war is the latest outbreak of violence that threatens lasting peace, not only in Israel and the Palestinian territories, but across the region and the globe.     Heavy rains cause partial dam collapse, flooding in Norway
    Storm Hans battered Norway with heavy rains Tuesday and Wednesday. Flooding of the Braskereidfoss power dam control room prevented the hatches from opening, causing a partial collapse and flooding downriver. The heavy rains provoked mudslides and swollen rivers which swept away some structures and flooded towns, requiring the evacuation of more than 3,000 people and isolating others.  ( 6 min )

Turkey is still in the middle of an emergency, reeling from the earthquake that killed at least 35,000 people last week. But the finger-pointing has already begun. The rush to punishment comes amid the grief, but also the mounting fury and frustration over the Turkish government’s earthquake response.     10 years ago, we were turning nuclear bombs into nuclear energy. We can do it again.
    Getty Images How we turned 20,000 Soviet nukes into zero-carbon energy — and how we can do the same with some of our own. Just a decade ago, one in 10 American lightbulbs was powered by dismantled Russian nuclear weapons. That was made possible by the Megatons to Megawatts program, an agreement negotiated after the collapse of the Soviet Union to convert uranium from Russia’s nuclear weapons stockpile into fuel for US nuclear power plants. The unconventional policy was first proposed by MIT physicist Thomas Neff in a 1991 New York Times op-ed. By the time Megatons to Megawatts ran its full course from 1993 to 2013, it had eliminated about 20,000 nuclear warheads and stood out as a point of shared pride in the often jaded arms control and disarmament field. “Nearly every commercia…  ( 15 min )

In the early hours of Monday, February 6, residents living in southern Turkey and northern Syria were woken by violent shaking, collapsing buildings, and sweeping blackouts. The earthquake buried residents in rubble and was followed by powerful aftershocks. By the following Monday, the death toll had passed 36,000 people. “It was like the apocalypse,” Abdul Salam al-Mahmoud, a resident of Atareb, Syria, told Reuters. The country is no stranger to quakes, having lost 17,000 people to a 7.4-magnitude tremor in 1999. But while last week’s earthquake was a 7.8-magnitude quake, and had an u…  ( 12 min )
